title: How to Sweep Your Own Chimney

steps.headline: Cut the brush down to a size a little bigger than that of the flue.
Holding  the old bed sheet over the fire opening, Duct tape all along the top  edge of the sheet, securing it to the top of the fireplace opening.
steps.description: Don't skimp on the tape - rigorous taping will keep the soot and debris  inside the fireplace and away from your room!

steps.headline: Place the correct sized brush inside the fire opening.
Take your leading rod and push it through the hole in the bed sheet.
Using your arm, hold the brush upright and connect the leading rod.
Now  is the time to really go to town with the Duct tape!
steps.description: Tape all of the  edges of the bed sheet to to the fireplace's opening to ensure that it  protects the room from soot. Try not to leave any gaps that debris can  fall through.

steps.headline: Push the leading rod up the chimney and connect another when needed, always turning to the right.
Repeat this process until you reach the top of the flue and then bring the rods back down, unscrewing them one by one as you go.
Take a look up the chimney using your torch.
steps.description: Still dirty? Repeat steps 5 to 10 until you are happy with the result.

steps.headline: Warm  the chimney up using a blow torch, or a hair dryer.
steps.description: Point the heat  source directly up the chimney for approximately 8 minutes.

steps.headline: Light  the smoke match or pellet and place it inside the fireplace's opening.
steps.description: If all the smoke goes up the chimney, then congratulate yourself on a  job well done! If it doesn't , then I would advise that you call in a  professional for help.

steps.headline: During  this smoke test, have a friend go outside and watch the pots on the  stacks.
steps.description: If smoke comes out of more than one pot, you have a leakage. If this is the case, call in a certified chimney sweep as soon as  possible.

steps.headline: When  the main bulk of the job is done, use a dustpan and brush and/or a  vacuum cleaner to clear the fireplace of soot and debris.
